results.title: Brush with royalty
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
A group of artists from Broken Hill prepare for an exhibition of their work in London. Artists include Pro Hart and Jack Absalom, and all use the countryside around Broken Hill as their source of inspiration. This film is recommended for students in Years 9-12.

results.title: Shoeshine girl
results.creator_credit: Peter Barton, Jane Startz and MacDonald Productions
results.brief_description: Story of a problem girl who goes to stay with her aunt during the summer vacation and the relationship she forms with the shoeshine man who hires her as his assistant. Raises issues concerning cooperation with others, and respect for the individual differences and beliefs of others.

results.title: Nutrition for sports: facts and fallacies
results.creator_credit: Stephen Wallen and Alfred Higgins Productions
results.brief_description: Looks at the dietary needs of people involved in physical activity. Discusses the basic components of a balanced diet and clearly shows the misconceptions that the general public has of the athlete’s nutritional requirements.

results.title: Play it safe electrically
results.brief_description: Warns children of the dangers of flying kites near overhead power lines; shows the dangers of climbing trees through which power lines run; identifies electircal substations and notes the inherent dangers; illustrates the consequences of touching fallen power lines and notes the dangers of using electrical equipment near water. Suitable for secondary level and teacher/tertiary level.

results.title: Fire drill!
results.creator_credit: Stephen Wallen and Alfred Higgins Productions
results.brief_description: Clearly outlines the procedure to be followed in a school should a fire break out. Indicates the need for alternative exit routes; what to do if all exit routes are blocked; and how to minimise the effects of smoke inhalation. Suitable for secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Schoolboy father
results.creator_credit: Arthur Allan Seidelman, Martin Tahse and Martin Tahse Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Learning to be human”.
Adaptation of the book “He’s my baby now” by Jeanette Eyerly, which focuses on a 16-year-old boy and his dilemma after learning that he has fathered a child. Determined to fill the parental void for his child, he finds himself confronting some harsh realities. Stars Rob Lowe and Dana Plato.

results.title: The Colonel comes to Japan
results.brief_description: Provides a fascinating look at the highly successful marketing of the Kentucky Fried Chicken product in Japan, noting the modifications to the standard American approach adopted to suit the Japanese business philosophy and life style. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Not by jeans alone
results.creator_credit: Louise Henry, KTEH-TV (Television station : San Jose, Calif.) and WGBH Educational Foundation
results.brief_description: Notes the market research into consumer behaviour that is carried out by the Levi company prior to the launching of a special range of tailored clothes for men. Shows the breakdown of the market into five distinct groups which have different reasons for purchasing clothes - eg status, work, and comfort; how the target group for the new range of clothes is determined; and how consumer discussion groups with members of this target group elicit their responses to the proposed range. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: One man's multinational
results.creator_credit: Ben Loeterman, Thomas Friedman and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description: Provides a history of the Bata shoe industry and then focuses on its operation as a multinational corporation. Raises issues surrounding the motivation behind the company’s installation of factories in Third World countries such as Kenya, highlighting the controversial nature of multinational corporations as such. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.
